passages.text: Initiating Coverage: UNDERPERFORM | PO: 7.20 SGD | Price: 7.77 SGD

We initiate coverage on ST Engineering (STE) at Underperform with a PO of S\\$7.2, based on the average of 23x P/E on 2026E earnings and DCF valuation. STE is a global engineering group with businesses across defense & public security (45% of FY25E revenue), commercial aerospace (38%), and urban solutions & satcom (17%). We think 1) the current valuation has fully priced in the top-/bottom- line potential from the new 5- year (2025- 29) plan; 2) a realistic overseas defense TAM of S\\$30bn is seen below headlines and market expectation; 3) NATO's preference for sovereignty, shifting spending priority, and member coordination challenges likely precludes near- term windfall scenarios.

On the domestic side (80%+ of total DPS revenue), we see limited upside as we expect Singapore's defense budget to stay at 3% of GDP over next decade. On the international side, while the market eyes on NATO's US\\$370bn (S\\$474bn) incremental budget, we see a more realistic revenue pool for STE at S\\$30bn (until 2035) from only a subset of NATO allies who do not have established defense industry. Every 1% of the S\\$30bn core defense increment captured only equals to a 3% boost in STE's group revenue.

STE has seized inventory shortage to export ammunition to Europe, thanks to its speed to the market. However, we see sovereignty and strategic autonomy as a long- term theme for NATO which means long- term spending will prioritize local suppliers. Further, the defense spending also trend against "hot ware" (armed vehicle, ammunition) but more on missile, drone, etc. areas, where STE is yet to gain international recognition.

STE's share price has rallied 70% year- to- date. We note that the current valuation has fully priced in the expectation for top- line/earnings growth from a new 5- year (2025- 29) plan and overseas order potential from multi- year defense upcycle. Compared with its relevant peers, STE's earnings growth is relatively modest while the valuation multiple is rich. Upside/downside risk: major defense order wins/delays.

Industrials/Multi- Industry

Established in 1967, ST Engineering is a leading global engineering group with businesses across the aerospace, smart city, defense, and public security segments. STE's core capabilities include aerospace MRO (#1 independent contractor globally by manpower hours), passenger- to- freighter conversion, defense land platforms, and urban mobility solutions.

We rate STE Underperform as we note that the current valuation has fully priced in the expectation for top- line/earnings growth from a new 5- year (2025- 29) plan and overseas order potential from multi- year defense upcycle. Compared with its relevant peers, STE's earnings growth is relatively modest while the valuation multiple is rich.

We initiate coverage on STE at Underperform with a PO of S\\$7.2, based on the average of \(23xP / E\) on 2026E earnings and DCF valuation. STE is a global engineering group with businesses across defense & public security (45% of FY25E revenue), commercial aerospace (38%), and urban solutions & satcom (17%). We think 1) the current valuation has fully priced in the top- /bottom- line potential from the new 5- year (2025- 29) plan; 2) a realistic overseas defense TAM of S\\$30bn is seen below headlines and market expectation; 3) NATO's preference for sovereignty, shifting spending priority, and member coordination challenges likely precludes near- term windfall scenarios.

STE is a Singapore- homegrown defense prime that is involved in land, sea, military aerospace, and digital systems/cybersecurity solutions. On the domestic side (80%+ of total DPS revenue), we see limited upside as we expect Singapore's defense budget to stay at \(3\%\) of GDP over next decade. On the international side, we see export/technology licensing opportunities for STE on NATO's incremental budget. However, instead of US\\$370bn (S\\$474bn) incremental budget from NATO, we believe a more realistic revenue pool for STE is S\\$30bn (until 2035) from a subset of NATO allies ("NATO Importers") that do not have established domestic defense industry and are open to integrating foreign capabilities. Every \(1\%\) of the S\\$30bn core defense increment captured only equals to a \(3\%\) boost in STE's group revenue.

STE has seized inventory shortage to export ammunition to Europe, thanks to its speed to the market. Although we see the \(3.5\%\) GDP budget target is likely to sustain for most NATO members, we caution that Europe faces many fundamental challenges when it comes to building out its defense ecosystem. We see sovereignty and strategic autonomy as a long- term theme for NATO which means long- term spending will prioritize local suppliers. Further, the defense spending also trend against "hot ware" (armed vehicle, ammunition) but more on missile, drone. etc. areas, where STE is yet to gain international recognition. We also think that defense planning alignment at the national and multinational level could be slowed by regulatory barriers and competing national interests, not to mention the innate political difficulties with reallocating existing fiscal programs.

STE is a global leading component OEM (for nacelles and floor panels) and the world's largest MRO service provider for commercial aircrafts. With 1) upcoming capacity expansion in three hangar hubs (the US, China, Singapore); and 2) MRO super- cycle resulted from a combination of older fleets, increased aircraft utilization, and likely higher MRO cost constrained by tight supply, we see commercial aerospace business well on track for \(6.5\%\) revenue CAGR target.

Our 12- month PO for STE is S\\$7.2, based on an average of \(23x2026E P / E\) multiple and DCF valuation. STE's share price has rallied \(70\%\) YTD. We note that the current valuation has fully priced in the expectation for top- line/earnings growth from a new 5- year (2025- 29) plan and overseas order potential from multi- year defense upcycle. Compared with its relevant peers, STE's earnings growth is relatively modest while the valuation multiple is rich. Key upside risk: major new defense orders; major increase in Singapore's defense budget; SGX's trading liquidity boost from MAS program; major new aerospace or smart city contracts; satcom business turnaround.

We initiate STE at Underperform with 12- month PO of S\\$7.2, based on equal weighted average of 23x 2026E P/E and DCF valuation. STE's share price has rallied 70% YTD. We note that the current valuation has fully priced in the expectation for top- line/earnings growth from a new 5- year (2025- 29) plan and overseas order potential from multi- year defense upcycle. Compared with its relevant peers, STE's earnings growth is relatively modest while the valuation multiple is rich.

We see the P/E valuation methodology as an appropriate metric, given 1) STE has concentrated business with \(80\% +\) revenue focused on defense & aerospace segment. 2) STE's strong earnings visibility, underpinned by order backlog and management's medium- term earnings- based target. 3) Newly announced earnings- based dividend policy. P/E valuation framework is also in- line with BofA global defense & aerospace coverage. We see EBITDA less suitable due to distortion from capitalized R&D depreciation, which varies from year to year, as well as R&D accounting variance based on funding type (client- funded vs. self- funded). We adopt DCF valuation as a second methodology which reflects the company's long- term earnings growth, cash flow management and generation, considering working capital and capex spending.

Assign 23x target P/E, benchmark with global defense peers median

The fair value of S\\$6.5 is derived from P/E valuation methodology, as we assign 23x target P/E to 2026E earnings. We adopt target P/E multiple of 23x, which is in line with global defense peers' multiple median. Though STE's earnings CAGR (13%) is lower than peers median (20%), we believe peers' median P/E is justified, given: 1) STE's international defense business is currently at a much earlier stage than peers, which implies a longer growth runway; 2) we see scarcity premium for STE as it is the only listed Singapore/ASEAN defense company and is a relatively under- owned/ recognized name by international investors; 3) superior ROE (27- 33%) vs. peers (15- 20%) and a higher dividend yield and dedicated shareholder- return enhancement.

STE is currently trading at 2SD vs. its historical mean, but we believe the historical valuation range is less relevant as it reflects aerospace business and domestic defense- related sales. The earnings CAGR is expected at 13% in 2024- 29E vs. 2.2% in 2015- 19 and 4% in 2019- 2024. Its main growth driver lies in international defense business (exports and licensing). We believe it is justified to compare with its peers group (European and Korean defense companies). Our target multiple equals to a 40% discount over closest European peer group (Rheinmetall, RENK, SAAB) and at a nearly 20% discount over closest Korean peer (Hanwha Aerospace), considering smaller defense product coverage of STE and smaller estimated revenue pool from NATO budget.

The fair value of S\\$7.9 is derived from our DCF calculation, with an assumption of 2.0% FCF perpetuity growth and 7.8% WACC. We sourced Beta of 0.85 from Bloomberg. We arrive at a WACC of 7.8%, comprising of risk free rate of 3% and equity risk premium of
7.0%. Lastly, we assign 2.0% perpetual growth rate to the company, which looks reasonable, considering normalized growth in the longer term.

Geopolitical events: the recent artillery depletion and the subsequent global rearmament wave was driven by prolonged geopolitical conflicts in Eastern Europe and Middle East. If these conflicts worsen, or new geopolitical events break out, STE could see more short- term defense export/licensing opportunities.

Domestic defense budget increase: already one of the most densely defended nations in the world with one of the highest defense spending per capita, Singapore has committed to maintain its \(3\%\) defense- to- GDP target over the next decade. If the gov't revises up this target, STE's domestic business will see substantial upside as the country's foremost defense prime.

Weakening of SGD: home currency depreciation would make STE's exports more competitive vs peers while boosting its margins as most of the costs are denominated in SGD (labor, technology, overheads, R&D).

Higher trading liquidity on SGX: in Feb 2025, MAS (Monetary Authority of Singapore) announced Equity Market Development Program (EQDP) in order to boost SGX's trading liquidity. First batch of \(\) 1.1\$ bn allocation was awarded in July to 3 local asset managers. The total allocation amount is equivalent to \(1.6\%\) of SGX turnover in 2024 (total: \(\) 306bn) and should provide a small boost to liquidity.

Peaceful resolution to geopolitical events: although we think higher defense spending is inevitable as ceasefire or end of war historically led to higher weapon purchases + restocking of arms to deter conflicts, a peaceful resolution to current geopolitical events would ease the urgency for hot weapon purchase and accelerate the shift from spending on short- cycle to long- duration categories. Gov't spending priority will also likely to shift as voters are "short memory" and defense spending has much lower fiscal multiplier vs e.g. investments in infrastructure, education.

Failure to finance defense spending increases: failure to finance defense budget increases by NATO allies impacted by recession, inflation, government change, or fiscal constraints would impair STE's international expansion.

Slowdown in airline passenger or cargo traffic: a broad slowdown in airline passenger or cargo volumes and hence, weaker aircraft utilization would put STE's MRO, passenger- to- freighter conversion, and aircraft leasing businesses to risk.

The world is moving into a decade of hard power investment. After setting new records each year since 2013, 2024 saw the steepest year- on- year rise in global military spend since at least the end of the Cold War, with over 100 countries raising their military budgets. Total world military expenditure reached \(\) 2.7\tan\(up 9.4\%\) in real terms from 2023 and on track to reach\) \ \(3.0\tan\) well before 2030, according to Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI).
Exhibit 14: 30 years of global defense spend by region (US\$bn) and as \(\%\) of world GDP (RHS) Global defense spending reached US\$2.7tn and is set to continue rise
Source: SIPRI, BofA Global Research

The US- China trade war, reinforced trade protectionism, unabated disputes around the South China Sea, prolonged conflicts in the Middle East, and Russia- Ukraine war have all led to elevated geopolitical tensions in the new era of Neo- Cold War. We foresee an unprecedented level of restocking and capital investment into replenishing weaponry system, which should result in an unabated demand growth for arms purchases/transfers over the coming years. While the biggest arms import growth was visible in European nations such as Ukraine and Poland, we see arms purchases and new order enquiries now spreading out to countries in Central Asia and the Middle East.

In June 2025, the NATO allies agreed to a \(5.0\%\) of GDP defense spending target by 2035. Of that figure, \(3.5\%\) is allocated towards core defense capabilities (equipment, personnel, maintenance) and \(1.5\%\) towards defense- related outlays (cyber, ports, energy pipelines etc.). NATO members will commit to annual plans to reach the \(5.0\%\) goal and a NATO review will take place in 2029. According to our European defense analysts, most countries in Europe have now articulated a plan on how they are going to achieve these higher levels of defense spending, and their commitment to the higher \(5.0\%\) targets. We see the \(5.0\%\) as a firm commitment that will stick. We estimate around \(\) 370bn\(incremental defense spending if all NATO members (ex - US) were to spend\) 3.5\% \(of GDP on core defense or a 2024 - 35E CAGR of\) >5.0\% \(in budgets.

Personnel has been a significant spending item in many NATO countries (Exhibit 17), but embedded in the goal of spending \(5\%\) GDP on defense, priorities will likely change. NATO partners of the US have significantly underinvested in equipment & infrastructure vs. the US (Exhibit 18). Within the \(\) 370bn\(incremental expenditure on core defense, we believe\) \% \(dollar allocated to equipment will likely increase from\) \leq 32\% \(in 2024 to\) \leq 40\%\$ through 2030, benefiting arms manufacturers around the world. (See our report: Global Defence: NATO moves to \(5\%\) of GDP - FAQ 29 June 2025)

Exhibit 15: NATO (ex-US) defense expenditure as % of GDP: 2024 Actuals vs 2035 Targets as declared at The Hague Summit June 2025 Among NATO (ex-US) members, only Poland's 2024 defense budget met the 3.5% of GDP target announced in June
Source:NATO,BofAGlobal Research
Exhibit 16: NATO (ex-US) spending by category (2024) Personnel and equipment (including R&D) are the largest categories
Source:NATO,BofAGlobal Research

Since Russia's full- scale invasion of Ukraine began in Feb 2022, European states have accelerated their modernization efforts. This has created opportunities for companies outside of Europe, which can either supply equipment more quickly than their European competitors or produce equipment that few or no European companies currently can, such as multiple rocket launchers (MRLs). Some politicians in Europe have criticized such acquisitions, arguing that Europe should procure from one another or collaborate to develop systems to build up the continent's 'strategic autonomy'. However, other countries, while supporting the overall ambition in the long term, have preferred to acquire non- European systems to achieve capability objectives more quickly.

From Feb 2022 to end- Oct 2024, South Korean companies secured production contracts worth US \(18bn from European states. The vast majority were contracted by Poland, which is seeking to rapidly modernize and expand the size of its armed forces. This includes the acquisition of large numbers of the Hanwha K9 Thunder tracked howitzers now ordered or operated by seven European countries. Israeli firms have also enjoyed success, signing US\) 6.85bn+ worth of contracts during this time frame. Although the sale of the IAI Arrow 3 ballistic- missile- defense system to Germany (US\)3.9bn) accounts for the most of this, it also includes the sale of Elbit Systems PULS MRLs to Denmark, the Netherlands, and Spain.
Exhibit 17: Defence spending ex-personnel, of total defence spending NATO (ex-US) has lagged behind the US in equipment and infra investments
Source:NATO,BofAGlobal Research

STE's NATO-standard ammunition exports breakthroughNATO's recent ammunition shortages – exposed by Russia/Ukraine war – have driven member states to urgently restock 155mm artillery rounds and other key ammunitions. In June 2024, STE's Land Systems division secured contracts worth totaling S\$100mn for NATO-standard 155mm and 40mm ammunition from new European customers, awarded via competitive tenders. The 155mm system notably adheres to NATO's joint ballistic and STANAG (Standard Agreement) interoperability standards, delivering extended-range high-explosive projectiles capable of reaching targets up to 30km with 39-caliber guns and up to 39km with 52-caliber guns. These strategically significant deals mark STE's breakthrough into Europe's high-barrier defense supply chain, where quality compliance and interoperability is essential. This foothold positions it to benefit from the multi-year replenishment programs driven by NATO's persistent ammunition shortfalls and opens door to orders and partnerships in other defense domains.
STE has successfully exported NATO standard 155mm and 40mm ammunition to European countries since 2024

We estimate S\$30bn incremental revenue pool for STE's international defense business from Europe's rearmament. While we expect most of NATO's incremental investments to go to European/American companies, we see a sizable export/technology licensing opportunity for STE from a subset of NATO allies ("NATO Importers") that do not have established domestic defense industry and are open to integrating foreign capabilities. The total military spend of this group of "NATO Importers" amounted to S\$88bn (US\$68bn) in 2024. If all countries raise their defense spend to 3.5% of GDP, there is an additional S\$30 defense boost ahead (at 5%/3% CAGR, if materialized in 2030E/2035E). Capturing every 1% of the S\$30bn core defense increment would mean a 3% boost to STE's group revenue (from 2025E).
Total estimated incremental spend from NATO importers to reach 3.5% GDP amounts to S\$30bn addressable market, equals to STE's current order book

Source: SIPRI, NATO, BofA Global Research estimates. NATO importers: Albania, Bulgaria, Croatia, Estonia, Hungary, Iceland, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovak Republic, Slovenia BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Every 1% of S\$30bn TAM captured would boost group revenue by 3%
Source: SIPRI, NATO, BofA Global Research estimates

The logical question, then, is how much of this revenue pool is STE expecting to capture? Unfortunately, it is very difficult to analyze at the current stage given the lack of budget details and financing plans for most of these countries. However, we know STE targets DPS revenue to grow to \(\) 7.5bn\(by 2029 from\) \ \(4.9bn\) in 2024. Assume all of this \(\) 52.6bn\(growth comes from the incremental defense orders of NATO importers, it implies\) 9\% \(of market share to the\) \ \(530bn\) revenue pool.

While we see most of the international opportunity lies in Europe, we recognize that the scale of the arms race globally and highlight potential order opportunities arising from increased defense budgets in other regions like non- NATO Eastern Europe and Middle East, North Africa, and Central Asia. Despite currently sharing a smaller portion of the global military spend than NATO (Exhibit 22), these regions are also witnessing rapid military build- ups (Exhibit 23). Often without mature domestic defense industries, these countries are also more open to foreign technologies, import substitutions, and/or setting up local manufacturing partnerships to boost domestic capabilities. Exports/partnerships to these regions could potentially provide more revenue upside.
We highlight NATO (ex- US), and non- NATO EMEA (mainly the Middle East) as potential regions for STE's international defense business expansion
Source: SIPRI, NATO, BofA Global Research estimates.

Although we see the \(3.5\%\) GDP budget target is likely to sustain for most NATO members, we caution that Europe faces many fundamental challenges when it comes to building out its defense ecosystem - from fragmented technical standards, complex regulatory barriers, competing national interests, to a hollowing industrial base and entrenched capability gaps from years of underinvestment. On one hand, these coordination challenges offered short- term unilateral order opportunities for non- European arm manufacturers, thanks to their much faster speed to market. On the other hand, we see sovereignty and strategic autonomy becoming key priorities to NATO, and any long- term coordinated investments will likely 1) prioritize European- domiciled suppliers; and 2) focus on strategic capability gaps like defense electronics, air defense, drones, etc. and lesser on "hot wares" like artillery and ammunition.

We also think that defense planning alignment at the national and multinational level could be slowed by regulatory barriers and competing national interests, not to mention the innate political difficulties with reallocating existing fiscal programs. This means that the road to NATO's \(3.5\%\) GDP target is likely to be messy and backloaded, and major orders for defense companies could take many years to materialize. In summary, multifaceted headwinds to Europe's rearmament ambition precludes a windfall scenario for defense companies around the world eyeing for a slice of the pie.

Exhibit 22: Global military spending CAGR by region (2010s vs 2020s) Eastern/Central Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East saw the fastest pace of military build-up since the Russia/Ukraine war broke out in 2022

Singapore ranks \(26^{\text{th}}\) globally in its total military budget but \(3^{\text{rd}}\) on per-capita basis only after Israel and the US. Notably, to counter its small armed force size, a significant portion of the budget each year is spent on capex, including investments in state- of- the- art defense systems and infrastructure.

Singapore's defense budget reached \(\) 523.5bn\(\) (\) 18bn) in 2025, representing the fourth double- digit increase in the past five years. While most of the adjustment addresses pandemic- era project delays, ex- defense Minister Ng Eng Hen has stated in 2024 that future budget will continue to remain around \(3\%\) of GDP over the next decade. Where it is more cost- effective to do so, MINDEF works with the local defense industry to build Singapore's own unique solutions, e.g., the Terrex Infantry Carrier Vehicle.

Singapore's 2025 budget increase will support major programs, incl. the Navy's plans to acquire two additional Type 218SG Invincible- class submarines, and new maritime patrol aircraft to replace its Fokker 50s. For the Air Force, 8 F- 35A fighters will be added to the 12 F- 35Bs already ordered. The Army will get a new \(8 \times 8\) Titan infantry fighting vehicle, and the existing High Mobility Artillery Rocket System will be upgraded for advanced missiles. To enhance its defense against drones, SAF has established a Counter- UAS group. Additionally, the first Multi- Role Combat Vessel designed for unmanned systems is also set to launch. These acquisition plans expand on the govt's recent defense initiatives, including an approved \(\) 133\$ mn purchase of Raytheon air- to- air missiles, a partnership with Safran to enhance weapon control against asymmetric threats, and a US- Singapore agreement to collaborate on responsible AI and data analytics in defense.

Cybersecurity: digital black swan for 2030?Cybersecurity is the #1 risk in a Transforming World because of how reliant we are on technology, in our view. The rise of Generative AI now creates a new 'threatscape'. Cybersecurity is increasingly becoming a matter of national security, with critical infrastructure more vulnerable to attacks. According to ENISA (European Union Agency for Cybersecurity), the top- 10 cybersecurity threats for 2030 are: 1) supply chain compromise of software dependencies, 2) skill shortage, 3) human error and exploited legacy systems within cyber- physical ecosystems, 4) exploitation of unpatched and out- of- date systems, 5) rise of digital surveillance authoritarianism / loss of privacy, 6) cross- border ICT (Information and Communications Technology) service providers as a single point of failure, 7) advanced disinformation / influence operations campaigns, 8) rise of advanced hybrid threats, 9) abuse of AI, and 10) physical impact of natural / environmental disruptions on critical digital infrastructure. With most targeted sectors: public administrations (19%), transport (11%), banking/finance (9%), and business service (8%).

Organizations around the world spent c.US\\$200bn in 2024 on cybersecurity, growing \(10\% +\) annually. The gap today between the US\\$200bn vended market and the fully addressable market is huge. At approximately \(10\%\) penetration of security solutions today, the total opportunity amounts to a staggering US\\$2.0tn addressable market. This does not imply the market will reach such a size any time soon. Besides, while most of the market is focused on the hardware now, we expect the software and services to increase significantly and take on a meaningful share through 2035.

Passenger traffic: in 2024, global passenger traffic was about 9.5bn travelers. The 20- year air passenger traffic CAGR is forecasted at \(+3.6\%\) with growing international travel from emerging markets (such as Asia Pacific and the Middle East) with rising middle classes and increased connectivity.

Cargo traffic: the total air cargo volume was 275bn CTK (cargo tonne- kilometers). With all the disruption of tariff and trade deals, cargo traffic frontloaded in early 2025 and is now fading as new trade barriers come in. Despite the short- term fluctuation, the 20- year air cargo traffic CAGR is expected at solidly \(+4.1\%\) with increasing supply chain diversification, eCommerce & logistics demand, and rising consumption.

Passenger fleet: in 2024, global commercial passenger fleet is expected at 29k aircraft. The 20- year passenger fleet CAGR at \(+3.2\%\) to meet soaring demand in air passenger traffic, replace aging aircrafts, corresponding increasing infrastructure.

Freight fleet: the global total air freighter was about 2.3- 2.4k aircrafts. The 20- year freighter fleet CAGR is forecasted at \(+2.6\%\) with a potential challenge of limited feedstock for freighter conversion, rising conversion costs, delays in aircraft certification, and deliveries.

STE's commercial aerospace OEM business consists of 1) nacelle production (new and spare parts) mainly for Airbus A320neo powered by the LEAP 1A engines (in partnership with Safran Nacelles), and 2) composite floor panel for the entire Airbus family (through joint venture with Airbus, EFW). Besides, STE also provides Passenger- to- Freighter conversion (P2F) at its hangars, and designs and manufactures innovative products such as AirFish (Wing- in- Ground craft), drones, and unmanned aircrafts.

For both nacelle and floor/interior businesses, we are seeing improving outlook as 1) bottlenecks are easing across engine supply chain (GE, Safran, and their component suppliers) (see our report Global Aerospace: GE CMD reads well for Safran and Airbus 18 July 2025), which bodes well for 2) Airbus to ramp up delivery into 2026/27 as the US- EU trade agreement removes uncertainty overhang. According to Oliver Wyman, global MRO demand is expected to see \(2.7\%\) CAGR in 2025- 35, with lower CAGR of \(2.1\%\) in 2025- 30E and accelerating into 2030- 35E at \(3.3\%\) CAGR. The MRO super- cycle is driven by older fleets remaining in service longer and newer fleets requiring maintenance sooner than anticipated to address reliability and durability issues: 1) Older fleets: the average age of planes in service rose to 13.4 years in 2024 from 12.5 in 2023 - an unprecedented rise for just one year. Airlines have continued to operate aging aircraft, which require more time in the hangar to retain similar levels of reliability compared with newer aircraft. 2) Longer flight hours: Average flight hours per aircraft increased almost \(15\%\) to 2,800 hours per year in 2024 from just over 2,400 in 2022.

STE continues to target double- digit growth in the international market, along with its reusable tech modules, standard- based tech, product innovation, and integrated approach.

Satcom: challenges remain from non- GEO constellationsNGSO (non- geostationary orbit) satellites refer to a type of orbit used by satellites in which the satellite is not stationary relative to the surface of the earth. NGSO satellites orbit the earth at a lower altitude and complete an orbit in a shorter period of time. Non- GEO (geostationary orbit) constellations such as Starlink, Europe's Iris2, and Amazon Kuiper continue to bring up the competition as NGSO satellites offer advantage such as: improved coverage, lower latency (faster communication speeds), lower cost, increased bandwidth, and greater flexibility. STE's satcom business continues to see challenges from industry disruption. Revenue saw \(9\%\) CAGR decline in 2020- 24 and exposure shrank from \(6\%\) (of group sales) to \(2\%\) . EBIT margin of the USS segment also was dragged by unprofitable satcom from \(3.5\%\) in 2020 to \(2.2\%\) in 2024. STE's new advanced satellite networking ground system, Intuition, has planned general release in end- Sep 2025 to deliver features such as standards, cloud, multi- orbit, and virtualization. It will take time for satcom business transformation and turnaround, in our view.

Revenue: at its Investor Day in March 2025, STE outlined a plan to reach S\$17bn revenue (ex- M&A) by 2029 at an implied CAGR of \(8\%\) p.a. or 2.5x the IMF's forecast of world GDP growth. The S\$17bn is underpinned by segmental targets: 1) CA: revenue growing 2x the industry to S\$6bn; 2) DPS: revenue to exceed S\$7.5bn; 3) Smart City (USS + the digital part of DPS): growing at 3.5x GDP to S\$4.5bn. Our forecasts (CA/DPS/USS 2024- 29E revenue CAGR at \(6.5\% /9.0\% /10.0\%\) ) are in line with these targets, considering STE's high revenue visibility from its order book (at 2.7x LTM sales), recent contract wins, delivery track record (achieved FY21 Investor Day targets well in advance), and potential pipeline businesses (from recently announced international partnerships, ongoing project bids/negotiations) not yet reflected in the order book.

Net income: as a part of the Five- Year Plan, STE targets to grow net profit at up to 5ppt higher CAGR than revenue and achieve S\$1bn total cost savings (1H25 was on track, with S\$100mn saved). Accordingly, we estimate group net profit to see \(13\%\) CAGR through 2029 on 20- 30bp p.a. EBIT margin expansion driven by: 1) scale effects of greater bargaining power and lower unit costs (materials, R&D); 2) productivity gains from enterprise resource optimization, offshoring production, and AI integration; and 3) improvement in product and project mix.

Our 25E EPS estimate is \(12\%\) above consensus, mainly as we factor in the divestment gains from LeeBoy and SPTel (which we believe is not yet reflected in consensus). Excluding this, our 25/26/27E EPS estimates are all \(7 - 8\%\) below consensus, driven by below- consensus revenue forecasts for DPS and USS and slightly lower EBIT margins.

Established in 1967, Singapore Technologies Engineering (STE) is a leading global engineering group with businesses across the aerospace, smart city, defense, and public security segments. Headquartered in Singapore, STE has evolved over the decades into a global leader in delivering integrated technology solutions to clients in over 100 countries. STE's predecessors were Singapore's earliest military contractors founded shortly after the city- state's independence. Then in 1997, they merged to form STE in an effort to boost international expansion. In 2016, STE onboarded current CEO Vincent Chong, who restructured the group's previously siloed segments into integrated clusters with shared functionalities and harmonized various products under one STE master brand. Present day, STE's core capabilities include aerospace MRO (#1 independent contractor globally by manpower hours), passenger- to- freighter conversion, defense land platforms, and urban mobility solutions. STE is a component stock of the MSCI Singapore, FTSE Straits Times Index, and Dow Jones Best- in- Class Asia Pacific Index.

Our PO is based on equal weighted average of 23x 2026E P/E and DCF valuation. For P/E valuation, our target multiple of 23x is in line with global defense peers' multiple median. We believe peers' median P/E is justified, given: 1) STE's international defense business is currently at a much earlier stage than peers, 2) we see scarcity premium for STE as it is the only listed Singapore/ASEAN defense company and is a relatively underrecognized name by international investors, 3) superior ROE vs. peers and a higher dividend yield and dedicated shareholder- return enhancement.

For DCF, we use a WACC of \(7.8\%\) , comprising of risk free rate of \(3\%\) and equity risk premium of \(7.0\%\) . Upside risks: 1) geopolitical events, 2) domestic defense budget increase, 3) weakening of SGD, 4) higher trading liquidity on SGX. Downside risks: 1) peaceful resolution to current geopolitical events delaying ammunition purchase, 2) failure for NATO to finance defense spending increase, 3) a slowdown in airline passenger or cargo traffic.
